title.en-US: Emulsify Design System and Higher Education

body.en-US:
Complex organizations with cross-functional teams, such as institutes of higher education, must often develop and maintain a multitude of websites. Maintaining an accessible, consistent design that reuses code and delivers an effective user experience within a single brand can be challenging.

Multiple teams have differing needs, goals, and ideas, and cross-department inefficiencies can slow down web project timelines and send costs skyrocketing. Stakeholders from one team might make changes to content or design on one site that creates inconsistency or errors, complicating maintenance costs and efforts. And for many organizations, failure to follow strict accessibility rules can result in costly and embarrassing regulatory violations.

## A design system is an ideal solution for university websites

These complex organizations need a design system that simplifies development, encourages consistency, reduces maintenance effort, and scales quickly and affordably — without hampering flexibility for individual developers, designers or departments.

Developers and designers need the ability to use the languages they know and tools that don’t restrict their creativity. CTOs and IT managers need tools that the entire team can use, that are affordable and well supported, and that help to reduce costs and increase productivity. And content and marketing managers need an easier way to encourage consistent branding across all site properties and to help ensure that all sites meet accessibility standards.

Design systems are meant to provide a single source of truth for an organization’s design — whether that’s one website or many. As the size and number of websites and products grow, it becomes even more important to have a design system that provides guidelines and developer tools — so new websites and pages can be built quickly and consistently. ## Western University of Pennsylvania (fictional university) We created a fictional higher education institution, Western University of Pennsylvania, to show how Emulsify can effectively manage a design system where there are overarching branding guidelines and schools with separate sub-branding.
[![Western U Homepage](//images.ctfassets.net/il3zdpvri0hi/5szv0ltb3vLyghjm2BCoMu/1f1d2e63bbee56af8ebbb76fdce00cf2/uni-demo.png)](https://western.emulsify.info/) ## University Website For this demo, we created a website for the university in Drupal, which shows what typical visitors would see when they come to the website. - [Western University website demo](https://western.emulsify.info/) - [Source code on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/westernuni)
[![Western Style Guide](//images.ctfassets.net/il3zdpvri0hi/4H4xGOI3pkL4U7OXQOsCjR/b5ae99a0568c75553541c2216283570b/uni-style.png)](http://western-identity.emulsify.info/) ### University Brand style guide The brand style guide contains all the documentation and assets needed for staff and students to properly use official university branding when creating future websites or materials. Many universities maintain this style guide completely separate from any website guidelines, which means they can easily get out of sync. With Emulsify, the shared elements of the style guide and component library never get out of sync, because they’re all part of the same design system. - [Brand style guide demo](http://western-identity.emulsify.info/) - [Source code on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/western-identity)
[![Western U Storybook Card Grid](//images.ctfassets.net/il3zdpvri0hi/o6xXWNubjIiIFeE1kjzCj/1f2a8d93ea4f1723971c6f0ffcdfe8ea/law-storybook.png)](https://western.emulsify.info/storybook/) ### University component library The university component library, powered by Storybook, is the tool developers use to build reusable components to use across all of the various university websites. These components include everything needed to create a web page: paragraphs, buttons, images, forms, menus, etc. Developers can also prototype page templates right inside the component library — such as a calendar, faculty directory, or course listing. We know accessibility compliance is important to universities, so we’ve included tools to perform accessibility testing on every component. - [Component library demo](https://western.emulsify.info/storybook/) - [University twig source code on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/western-up-twig) - [University sass components source code on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/western-up-scss)
## School of Studio Arts The Studio Arts demo is an example of a typical school or college website within a university. You can see the website follows the university’s brand style guide for its use of color and typography. It also shares common web components such as the header and footer. Being an art school, they should be given the freedom to customize the look and feel of their website. One example is customizing the appearance of cards for linking to articles — in this case using an asymmetrical layout and text overlays instead of the [standard university card grid](https://western.emulsify.info/storybook/?path=/story/organisms-grids--card-grid). Because of this, the arts school has its own component library (also in Storybook) to document any components that deviate from the primary style guide.
[![Arts Demo](//images.ctfassets.net/il3zdpvri0hi/2zi5mDDlmPZ99Fwj80swH1/b09359240c4b80f2add3c237d867c20f/arts-demo.png)](https://western-arts.emulsify.info/) ### Studio Arts Website The Studio Arts website was also built using Drupal, so it can share both the Twig component markup and styling with the parent. All that was needed to create this website was to create the custom components specific to the Stuido Arts project. - [School of Studio Arts demo](https://western-arts.emulsify.info/) - [Source code on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/westernarts)
[![art storybook new](//images.ctfassets.net/il3zdpvri0hi/2oG9o2qNYAYEGgIHb1SDyf/9d5741cef31aee9040226185a3c7f3d0/localhost_6006__path__story_organisms-art-grid--home.png)](https://western-arts.emulsify.info/storybook) ### Studio Arts component library You can choose what you want to show in the component library (any combination of organization and property components). In this case, we chose to show only the components unique to the Studio Arts project. - [School of Studio Arts Component Library Demo](https://western-arts.emulsify.info/storybook) - [Source code for Arts website components on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/westernarts/tree/master/web/themes/custom/western_arts/components)
## School of Law The School of Law demo is another example of a typical school or college within a university. The interesting part about the School of Law is that it is built using [React](https://reactjs.org/) and [Gatsby](https://www.gatsbyjs.org/). This means that while it cannot share the markup used in the Drupal projects because those were written in Twig, it can still leverage styling from the parent project because that has been logically separated out into its own package. The School of Law website just needed to match the University's branding exactly, which left us free to reuse the design and styles, so all we had to do was write the new React components. And since those have been separated out into [their own package](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/western-up-react) as well, we can reuse them on any future React projects.
[![Western Law Homepage](//images.ctfassets.net/il3zdpvri0hi/6ACrNs0agBHTb7fOATKHF2/97b9610b575f60ca02cbf8ccbff48b4b/law-demo.png)](https://western-law.emulsify.info/) ### School of Law Website - [School of Law demo](https://western-law.emulsify.info/) - [Source code on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/western-law)
[![Western Law Storybook](//images.ctfassets.net/il3zdpvri0hi/3ES1kTe6A9zJNriWb1SF4u/3fec992e1ca637c102d27598064ba366/law-storybook.png)](http://western-law-storybook.emulsify.info/) ### School of Law component library - [School of Law Component Library Demo](http://western-law-storybook.emulsify.info/) - [Source code for Law Gatsby website on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/western-law) - [Source code for Law website React components on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/western-up-react)
## Using Emulsify to build higher education websites Want to learn more about how a design system can benefit a university’s ecosystem of websites? Check out this article on Emulsify and higher education, which outlines the benefits of modularity, parallel development, faster onboarding, and accessibility/visual regression testing.

title.en-US: Get ready to learn all about Emulsify with our fresh blog

moreLinkText.en-US: Learn why we have a blog

description.en-US: We want to communicate what is going on in the world of design systems, Drupal themes, WordPress themes, design tokens, and Emulsify with you.

body.en-US:
The Emulsify team and community has a lot of energy going around this project and we wanted a place to share it all.
- Upcoming features
- How-to videos and guides
- Contributor features
- More!

title.en-US: Frontend & Figma Magic, Building a Connected UI Kit for Emulsify

moreLinkText.en-US: See the UI Kit in action

description.en-US: Website production has always progressed while navigating a broad divide: the line separating visual design and frontend development. Now, through Emulsify harnessing Figma’s design tokens plugin, design and development teams can enjoy an automated communication connection.

body.en-US:
## Introducing the alpha version of the Emulsify UI Kit!

By bringing Emulsify together with Figma, the historic barrier between design and development is blown apart. In this recorded presentation from Decoupled Days in New York, we’ll show you how any web project can progress faster and more efficiently than before.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/bt0CKVGkl-c" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

### Where to find the UI Kit
- [Emulsify UI Kit on Github](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/emulsify-ui-kit)
- [UI Kit Storybook](https://four-kitchens-ui-kit.netlify.app/?path=/story/cover-cover--cover)
- [Figma UI Kit Community File](https://www.figma.com/file/1141071510618977331)

description.en-US: The Emulsify project has grown a lot since it first launched in 2016. We have thousands of people using it across Drupal and WordPress and a vibrant community of contributors. To celebrate, we are working with you, the community, to create a roadmap for Emulsify that will guide us into the future.

body.en-US:
## The Emulsify project has grown a lot since it first launched in 2016. 
We have thousands of people using it across Drupal and WordPress and a vibrant community of contributors.

The best way to commemorate this six-year milestone is by refocusing our energy on Emulsify. We are working with you, the community, to create a roadmap for Emulsify that will guide us into the future. To make this happen we have hired [Greg Storey at Airbag Industries](https://airbagindustries.com/) to research the market surrounding Emulsify. Our goal is to have a roadmap to a strong, better Emulsify that serves your needs.

If you want to skip ahead and just read the Research PDF, jump to the bottom of this article.

## The Project Team
- [Greg Storey](https://www.linkedin.com/in/brilliantcrank/), Project Lead
- [Colin Narver](https://www.linkedin.com/in/colinnarver/), Research Lead
- [Brett Harned](https://www.linkedin.com/in/brettharned/), Research Lead
- [Randy Oest](https://www.linkedin.com/in/amazingrando/), Creative Director at Four Kitchens
- [Brian Lewis](https://www.linkedin.com/in/brian-lewis-ks/), Frontend Architect and Senior Frontend Engineer at Four Kitchens

## Research
The team conducted a series of conversations with project stakeholders, design system subject matter experts, and Emulsify contributors and users. 
In addition, a public survey was conducted the week of July 25, 2022. 

## Key Insight Highlights
The following are a few of the insights from the research.
- There is confusion regarding Emulsify’s past state as a design system and its current state as a bespoke design system builder. Today, developers see Emulsify as a Drupal Theme with Atomic components and basic tokenization. 
- Emulsify should continue development beyond Drupal while engaging deeply with the Drupal community. 
- Investment in proper analytics is essential to assess progress towards milestones. 
- People want to contribute to Emulsify but are confused as to what and how. Pull requests and contribution approvals take too long. 
- Emulsify is a great way to introduce code cohesion, development principals, and process alignment between developers. 
- FEDs want to use Emulsify to improve their work with designers and get designers to be component driven (where it makes sense). 

## SWOT Analysis 

### Strengths 
- Able to flexibly support dynamic content distribution needs at scale. 
- The sweet spot for higher education, government, and media organizations with integration to Drupal. 
- Open source solution built for the Drupal community by the Drupal community. 
- Emulsify is a proven, dependable tool currently deployed at all scale levels. 

### Weaknesses 
- Identity Crisis: Developers are unsure what Emulsify’s grand intention is - a design system or a tokenized theme, or both. 
- Uncertain if decoupling design components from starter makes sense to anyone outside Four Kitchens. 
- Lack of dedicated evangelism. 
- Contributors have to wait too long for pull requests and submissions. 
- Incomplete data on distribution and downloads, No data on downloads through Github or CLI. 
- Emulsify needs better representation on the Drupal website, a primary marketing tool. 
- The Emulsify website needs improvements to be on par with other design system management and template/theme products. 

### Opportunities 
- Design systems and tokens are still in their infancy in their shared definition and successful use at scale. 
- Grow thought leadership through teaching and advocating best practices. 
- Increasing clarity of what and how people can contribute to Emulsify. 
- Evangelism on design systems and Emulsify at large. Bring designers and their work into the product. 
- Find ways to bring designers into the project as contributors. 
- Create a multi-tenet tool that works across teams and tech stacks.

### Threats  
- Too much confusion on what Emulsify is and what it does (design system tool vs. design system). 
- Current users are dominantly FEDs who only see their design system as a tool. 
- As most Emulsify users see the product as a Drupal theme, there are a lot of competing “design systems” for Drupal. 
- Investment costs in Emulsify are low, and switching tools is too easy.

## The Research Document
[Emulsify Research Playback v1.1](/emulsify-research-playback.pdf)

title.en-US: Specbee teaches how Emulsify Twig makes it easy to write BEM CSS class names

description.en-US: The BEM (Block, Element, Modifier) methodology is a widely used naming convention for CSS classes that is popular because of the ease of use it offers. Find out how Emulsify Twig makes it easy in Drupal.

body.en-US:
We recommend reading ["What is BEM (Block, Element, Modifier) and How can it be used with Drupal Emulsify Twig"](https://www.specbee.com/blogs/bem-block-element-modifier-with-drupal-emulsify-twig) to learn more about what BEM is and how to implement it in Drupal templates.

> In Drupal, we can use the BEM Twig function with the help of the [Emulsify Twig module](https://github.com/emulsify-ds/emulsify_twig). The BEM function lets you create BEM classes on elements in the components. 
> 
> BEM methodology is extremely useful to developers who want to write and maintain better quality code that can be easy to be handed over and understood. Every element has a purpose which can be easily identified by its name and which block it is coming from. When used right, you will see that using BEM can boost development speed.

title.en-US: Introducing the design tokens file format (from Schema 2022)

description.en-US: The Design Tokens Community Group (DTCG) is defining a standard design tokens file format, which aims to make sharing design tokens between different tools seamless.

body.en-US:
The Emulsify team is keenly watching the work of the Design Tokens Community Group and their presentation during Schema 2022 is a great introduction to the upcoming design token file format.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ssOdzxZdg58" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

title.en-US: Adding a JS library to an Emulsify Component in Drupal

description.en-US: Adding a JavaScript library to an Emulsify component may seem daunting if you're new to the process, but it's not as complicated as it may seem. In this guide, we'll show you how to add a JavaScript library to an Emulsify component step-by-step, using the Swiper library as an example.

title.en-US: An Emulsify Drupal site is up for a Webby! Go vote!

description.en-US: The Wu Tsai Institute website, built with Emulsify, has been nominated for a Webby Award in the School/University and Best Mobile Visual Design Aesthetic categories! The website was built using Drupal and uses Emulsify for theming. The Webby Awards are determined by a panel of judges and popular vote, so everyone is encouraged to vote for the website on the Webby Awards website.

body.en-US:
We are thrilled to announce that the Wu Tsai Institute website, which is built with Emulsify, has been nominated for a Webby Award in two categories! The Webby Awards are the leading international awards honoring excellence on the Internet, and we are honored to have an Emulsify site among the nominees.

The [Wu Tsai Institute website](https://wti.yale.edu/) was built using Drupal, a powerful content management system, and we used Emulsify for theming, which helped us create a beautiful and user-friendly design. The team at [Four Kitchens](https://www.fourkitchens.com/) worked hard to create a website that reflects their mission and values, and we are proud of what we have accomplished.

But we need your help to win! The Webby Awards are determined by a panel of judges as well as by popular vote, so we need our community to come out and support us. Please take a moment to visit the Webby Awards website and cast your vote for the Wu Tsai Institute website in the following categories:
* [School/University](https://vote.webbyawards.com/PublicVoting?#/2023/websites-and-mobile-sites/general-websites-and-mobile-sites/schooluniversity)
* [Best mobile visual design aesthetic](https://vote.webbyawards.com/PublicVoting#/2023/websites-and-mobile-sites/mobile-specific-features-design/best-mobile-visual-design-aesthetic)

Thank you for your support, and let's bring home the trophy for Emulsify!
